awd_titl_txt: CM: Machine-Learning Driven Decision Support in Design for Manufacturability
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditional design and manufacturing relies on the experience and training of the designer to create a component with manufacturable features. However, even after careful design, the as-manufactured part might differ from the as-designed part. In addition, the inclusion of certain features might significantly increase the manufacturing cost. For example, the inclusion of a thin feature might necessitate the use of complex jigs or fixtures to prevent the flexing of the part during machining, which increases manufacturing time and cost. This problem is also encountered in additive manufacturing, where there is no body of knowledge regarding design rules that will reduce manufacturing defects. This project aims to address this challenge by developing computer-aided design tools that can identify difficult-to-manufacture features using machine learning. The process of identification of the source of infeasibility in manufacturing in a complex part is a challenging task, even for an experienced designer. Therefore, the use of machine learning could potentially play a critical role by detecting non-intuitive patterns from examples of feasible and infeasible parts, and identifying the source of infeasibility. The results of the machine-learning framework will be used to build a decision support framework that can interactively identify manufacturability concerns during the design process and present design modifications interactively to the designer. Finally, the multidisciplinary components of the project will be integrated into a larger educational effort to offer students a solid foundation in the critical interdisciplinary area of cyber-enabled manufacturing.

The objective of this project is to create a design for manufacturability tool that uses machine learning to identify difficult to machine or manufacture features in a computer-aided design model and suggest changes to the non-manufacturable features. The novelty of this research is the use of machine learning in a computer-aided design and manufacturing environment, making it accessible to designers using a familiar design interface. The research team will develop tools for loading existing models of parts and performing virtual machining simulations to create a digital voxelized representation of the as-manufactured part. The original as-designed part will also be converted to a voxelized representation that will be suitable for machine learning. The machine-learning framework will be trained using multiple machining simulations and will classify feasible and infeasible designs by learning from positive and negative examples. Furthermore, the machine-learning framework will be used to present alternative feasible designs to the designer.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In this research work, the research team developed novel machine learning-based computational frameworks for design and manufacturing. Some of the key contributions are: (i) a fast preprocessing software for computer-aided design (CAD) using graphics processing units (GPUs) to convert traditional models to a voxel-based representation; (ii) an automated design for manufacturing tool for drilled holes using deep learning; (iii) a machine learning-based surrogate model for the design and analysis of bioprosthetic heart valves; (iv) a machine learning accelerated method for structural topology optimization; (v) a CAD-aware machine learning module for surface reconstruction; and (vi) a computational software tool for direct 3D printing of voxelized models.

While traditional design and manufacturing rely on the experience and training of the designer to create a component, this project addresses this challenge by developing machine learning and GPU accelerated software tools manufacturing decision support. These decision support frameworks can help design engineers make informed decisions and interactively obtain design modifications during the design process.

This research was one of the first NSF-funded research projects on using machine learning for engineering and manufacturing applications. The scientific findings of the work were published in top academic journals and conferences in machine learning, design, and manufacturing. The team published 18 peer-reviewed conference/journal articles, a book chapter, and several conference publications. Many of these publications received significant media attention. Some of the publications include top machine learning conferences such as NeurIPS (with acceptance rate < 30%), and journals such as Additive Manufacturing (Impact Factor 10.998) and npj Scientific Reports (Impact Factor 4.3).

As part of the broader impacts of the project, the principal investigators developed materials for the graduate courses Solid Modeling and GPU Computing and Data Analytics and Machine Learning for Cyber-Physical Systems. The course projects of both these courses helped disseminate the knowledge on cybermanufacturing to graduate students and the next generation workforce. The resulting software packages were open-sourced and available through the project website. The project directly supported 2 Ph.D. students, 2 Masters' students, and 3 undergraduate students. In addition, one Masters's and two undergraduate students supported by the project were female.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2021
Modified by: Adarsh Krishnamurthy

Images (1 of )
  • Framework for deep-learning-based design for manufacturability. The CAD model is converted to a voxel representation and input to a 3D-CNN for manufacturability classification.
    Sambit Ghadai, Aditya Balu
    Public Domain
    Adarsh Krishnamurthy
    Machine Learning DFM
  • Deep-learning-based convolutional autoencoder for predicting the output deformations and the coaptation area of the heart valve in the closed state, with the BHV leaflet reference geometry, material properties, and the aortic pressure as input.
    Aditya Balu
    Public Domain
    Adarsh Krishnamurthy
    DL for Heart Valves
  • Deep learning-based topology optimization framework. The input to this framework is the compliance of the initial geometry along with the target volume fraction. The framework predicts the optimal density of the geometry without any requirement of iterative finite element evaluations.
    Jaydeep Rade, Aditya Balu
    Public Domain
    Adarsh Krishnamurthy
    Topology Optimization
  • Pipeline of our direct 3D printing approach. The CAD model is converted into a multi-level voxel representation used to create the G-code for direct printing. Print comparison of our MLMS approach with standard STL printing. Our approach has a better surface finish with lower staircasing artifacts.
    Anushrut Jignasu
    Public Domain
    Adarsh Krishnamurthy
    Direct 3D Printing
